awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Designing synthesizable, ligand-protected bimetallic nanoparticles and modernizing engineering curriculum through computational nanoscience
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a novel open-access computational framework for predicting the growth mechanisms and morphologies of ligand-protected metal nanoparticles (NPs). With NPs impacting numerous fields of science and technology, from energy to medicine to the environment, there is a critical need to determine the growth mechanisms of ligand-protected metal NPs and predict NP morphologies that can be synthesized in the laboratory. Although metal nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes and shapes can be synthesized by colloidal chemistry methods,  advances towards controlling NP morphology have been based largely on trial and error experimentation, which is often tedious and costly. The proposed computational framework will employ novel first-principles-based structure-property relationships accounting for structure sensitivity and metal composition. The integration of research and education efforts will focus on modernizing the traditional Chemical Thermodynamics course by introducing animation modules based on cutting-edge nanotechnology examples.  Outreach activities are planned through a nanoscale-inspired interactive computer game to engage high school students, including underrepresented minorities, into pursuing STEM careers and increase awareness about the importance of the field of nanotechnology.

The proposed research project will combine Density Functional Theory methods with Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics simulations, Machine Learning, and scientific computing to develop a novel, open-access computational framework, applicable to the design of ligand-protected NPs. This framework will generate a library of crystal structures and electronic properties of thermodynamically stable, thiolate-protected, Au-based bimetallic NPs, across a range of heterometals and particle morphologies, all under realistic experimental conditions. The proposed work aims to advance current theories on NP stabilization, which are based on simplified, electron counting rules. The proposed computational framework will enable rational design of ligand-protected NPs.  It will also elucidate NP growth steps that are experimentally intractable, thus accelerating nanomaterials discovery.  The research findings will be made available online for experimental verification.

por.por_cntn:
Metal nanoparticles find tremendous applications in diverse areas ranging from energy conversion and production of fuels and chemicals, to sensing and drug delivery. The application properties of metal nanoparticles are directly related to their compositional and morphological characteristics. Although controlled synthesis of metal nanoparticles has been achieved with colloidal chemistry methods, these have heavily relied on trial-and-error experimentation. In this project we used computational chemistry, scientific computing, machine learning and data science to understand how colloidal metal nanoparticle structural parameters, such as metal composition in multimetallic nanoparticles, nanoparticle size and shape, and presence of surface ligands, dictate overall nanoparticle stability and electronic properties. In addition, we revealed reaction mechanisms and physicochemical processes that result in controlled growth of colloidal nanoparticles. This computational work provided insights into nanoscale chemical processes, difficult to track with experiments, and guidelines for targeted, structurally controlled experimental synthesis of metal nanoparticles with atomic level precision. The computational predictions were verified by a series of experiments through collaborations with several experimental groups.

Research Outcomes: The project introduced a series of structure property relationships providing a computational framework for the design of colloidal nanoparticles with optimal thermodynamic stability. The parameters taken into consideration in the controlled synthesis of colloidal nanoparticles include the type of ligands, type of metals, metal composition in multimetallic nanoparticles and nanoparticle size and shape, through detailed coordination environments of metal atoms comprising the nanoparticles. Moreover, a series of electronic and application properties (e.g. electron affinity, ionization potential, CO2 electrocatalytic reduction activity and selectivity, etc.) were shown how to trend as a function of nanoparticle structure, connecting structurally controlled nanoparticle synthesis with application behavior. The developed models capture nanoparticle behavior from sub-nano to nanoscale (particles consisting of number of metal atoms ranging from tens to thousands of atoms) providing new avenues for the computational-informed design of metal nanoparticles bridging synthesis with application performance. Concepts developed from this research on colloidal nanoparticles were shown to be applicable to understanding and controlling crystal growth in biomineralization processes (e.g. kidney stones). Research results have been published in more than 30 scientific articles and reported in a rich database with ligated nanoparticles.

Broader Impacts: The project contributed to the training of 5 PhD students and 3 undergraduate researchers on computational chemistry methods, machine learning, scientific computing, and data science. On the educational aspects of the project, student response questions and teaching material have been developed, incorporating ligated bimetallic and multimetallic nanoparticle research into the course of Chemical Thermodynamics with goal to exemplify thermodynamic misconceptions. On the educational outreach, an online game (Nanocluster Explorer) and a structure visualization program (Molgif) have been developed to engage high school students to nanoscience. Finally, a rich database of ligated nanoparticles has been developed and shared with the scientific community. The results from this research have the potential to impact any area of nanoparticle application, ranging from synthesis to catalysis. In addition, this research informs diverse areas, where controlled crystal growth is of central importance. Examples include manipulation of crystal stability relevant to kidney stone growth inhibition and dissolution, as well as pharmaceuticals stability and controlled release.
